Note down the dimensions: * Length: 0.0852 * Width: 0.375 * Height: 0.0852</description>

The euler angles should be set to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] degrees and the translation vector should be set to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. This will ensure the coordinate system is aligned with the default orientation. Now, create a sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. The sketch should have two faces: face_1 and face_2. On face_1, create two loops: loop_1 and loop_2. * Loop_1 should be made up of four lines: line_1, line_2, line_3, and line_4. + line_1 should start at [0.0, 0.0] and end at [0.075, 0.0]. + line_2 should start at [0.075, 0.0] and end at [0.075, 0.075]. + line_3 should start at [0.075, 0.075] and end at [0.0, 0.075]. + line_4 should start at [0.0, 0.075] and end at [0.0, 0.0]. * Loop_2 should be made up of four lines as well: line_5, line_6, line_7, and line_8. + line_5 should start at [0.003, 0.003] and end at [0.072, 0.003]. + line_6 should start at [0.072, 0.003] and end at [0.072, 0.072]. + line_7 should start at [0.072, 0.072] and end at [0.003, 0.072]. + line_8 should start at [0.003, 0.072] and end at [0.003, 0.003]. Each loop is closed, and they are constructed such that the face is formed properly in 3D space upon extrusion. After creating the loops, scale the sketch by a factor of 0.075. Then, transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector from the coordinate system. Extrude the sketch along the Z-axis by 0.75 units to create the 3D model of the prism. The length of this part is 0.075 units, the width is 0.075 units, and the height is 0.75 units. With these instructions, the junior CAD designer should be able to generate the first part of the final shape, which is the long, rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom.</description>
